prompt:
You act as a player of an interactive text adventure game. The goal is to win the game.
The user provides the text of the text adventure, as well as the initial scenario.
The user is not a human and will only prints the output of the game.

Your task is to respond with simple commands, typically one or two words.
name: shade.z5

messages.content:
*** SHADE ***
A brief story by "Ampe R. Sand" (Andrew Plotkin)
First-time players should type "about".
Release 3 / Serial number 001107 / Inform v6.21 Library 6/10 

Odd, how the light just makes your apartment gloomier. Pre-dawn darkness pools in the corners and around the tops of walls. Your desk lamp glares yellow, but the shadows only draw your eyes and deepen.

Not much of an apartment, no. One desk, paper-piled, with a dusty computer shoved to the side. Your futon. Second-hand stereo sitting on a cardboard crate. A kitchen nook one way and a bathroom nook the other, with a closet to the side. A broad mirror tries to make the place seem twice its size; it halfway works. One window, whose shade is down, and the front door firmly shut.

Your luggage is piled untidily by the door. A potted hyacinth sits beneath the window.

You are sprawled on the futon, staring up into that gloom. Your eyes feel gritty. But it's too late -- early -- no time left for sleep, anyway. In a few hours your ride will arrive.

On the desk are your to-do list and a travel book.

>
look around

I only understood you as far as wanting to look.

>
examine desk

The desk is, of course, an organized mess; overlapping piles of paper, inches high. The computer is a dusty beige block, several generations out of date, poking up hopefully from among the strata. The lamp hangs over all.

A game-over message is flashing on the screen.

You see your to-do list and a travel book on the desk.

>
examine to-do list

You won't accomplish much while slumped on the futon. That's been getting slowly more apparent for hours now.

>
get up

You lever yourself upright. Umf. It's amazing how much lack of sleep feels like a hangover, only without the preceding party.

>
examine travel book

You sit down at the desk.

The Schmendrick's Guide to Desert Camping -- you've been studying it for weeks now. Vast alien reams of information: perspiration rates, sunburn factors, tent guying, and how to make a condensation still out of a trashbag and a tin can. You could probably write the book out longhand from memory; and none of it means a damn thing to you.

(That's why you're going on this trip, after all. It is, of course, the Death Valley Om -- half arts festival, half cult, a week in the deep desert where people show off, have sex, take drugs, and maintain a twenty-four-hour constant OM. Sand, heat, and thousands of throats. A space outside the world; with no dues except that you join in the chant, as much as is in you to chant.)

Come to think of it, as with a hangover, dehydration is probably the problem. Your mouth is dry wool.

>
get water

Which do you mean, the water from the bathroom sink, the water from the shower or the water from the kitchen sink?

>
kitchen sink

You stand up, and step into the kitchen nook.

You have nothing in which to carry water.

>
find container

You can't see any such thing.

>
check bathroom

You step out of the kitchen nook.

The bathroom alcove has a toilet, a sink, and a shower stall that manages to make the rest of the place look roomy. Not much else; most of your accoutrements have been packed.

>
return to kitchen

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
go back to kitchen

You can't see any such thing.

>
search apartment

You survey your one small room. One desk, paper-piled, with a dusty computer shoved to the side. Your futon. Second-hand stereo sitting on a cardboard crate. A kitchen nook one way and a bathroom nook the other, with a closet to the side. A broad mirror tries to make the place seem twice its size; it halfway works. One window, whose shade is down, and the front door firmly shut.

The place is still too dim, except the corner where the desk lamp is somehow too bright.

Your luggage is piled untidily by the door. A potted hyacinth sits beneath the window.

On the desk are your to-do list and a travel book.

>
check luggage

You've packed and repacked: breakdown tent, dried food, sunscreen, compass, mylar space-blanket, long underwear and showoff tats, walking shoes and dancing shoes and hiking shoes. You're ready for the Death Valley Om.

(As ready as you're likely to get. Nothing is off-limits at the Om. "Law ends at sea level." In one place in the country, for one week, a community is formed from pure will. No enforcement; only desire, and the knowledge of what the desert can do. And the Om. Every religion chants, you remember reading that.)

>
look for container in luggage

You can't see any such thing.

>
check closet

The closet (if you can call it that) is a shallow recess next to the bathroom. Peering into the (ahem) depths, you see an old jacket and a vacuum cleaner.

You're still feeling thirsty.

>
examine potted hyacinth

This plant is your one claim to actual responsibility. The hyacinth sits by the window, soaking up sunlight (when it's not night) and managing to thrive despite your lack of gardening skill. Although it looks a little parched at the moment.

>
water hyacinth

You're not carrying any water.

>
return to bathroom

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
go to bathroom

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine sink in bathroom

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine shower

You step into the bathroom nook.

The shower stall is a familiar symphony in pinkish-grey tile and grunge. Well, more of a solo. A short solo.

>
check shower for container

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the shower.

>
search shower

The shower stall is a familiar symphony in pinkish-grey tile and grunge. Well, more of a solo. A short solo.

>
check under sink

You can't see any such thing.

>
go to kitchen

You can't see any such thing.

>
search kitchen

You step out of the bathroom nook.

The kitchen alcove has a refrigerator, a sink, a stove, and barely enough space to stand between them. One wall projects out to form a counter, with a cupboard beneath it.

On the kitchen counter is a glass.

>
take glass

You step into the kitchen nook.

Taken.

>
examine refrigerator

You can't see any such thing.

>
open cupboard

You open the cupboard, revealing a box of crackers.

>
take glass from counter

You can't see any such thing.

>
take crackers

Taken.

You run your tongue over dry teeth.

>
return to bathroom

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
go to bathroom

You can't see any such thing.

>
go to kitchen

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine potted hyacinth

This plant is your one claim to actual responsibility. The hyacinth sits by the window, soaking up sunlight (when it's not night) and managing to thrive despite your lack of gardening skill. Although it looks a little parched at the moment.

>
search for water source

You can't see any such thing.

>
check under the sink in kitchen

You can't see any such thing.

>
look outside window

I only understood you as far as wanting to look.

>
examine window

The shade is drawn.

>
raise shade

You step out of the kitchen nook.

Darkness is already crawling around the edges of the windowshade. You have no desire to look night in the face.

>
pull shade down again

I only understood you as far as wanting to pull the windowshade.

>
close windowshade

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine door

The front door is white and rectangular -- yes. The door is closed.

>
open door

The sun hasn't risen; what light you have would just leak out into the night. Anyway, the taxi hasn't arrived, so there's nowhere to go.

You're still feeling thirsty.

>
check kitchen sink for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the kitchen sink.

>
examine kitchen sink

You step into the kitchen nook.

The kitchen sink is spotless. Not through any virtue of yours, mind you, except for your inability to cook.

>
turn on faucet

(the kitchen sink)
Nothing comes from the tap but an eerie distant howling. The kitchen sink hasn't worked since you moved in.

>
check refrigerator for water

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine potted hyacinth for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the hyacinth.

>
examine hyacinth for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the hyacinth.

>
check for any remaining water sources in bathroom

You can't see any such thing.

>
search apartment for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to search the living room.

>
search living room

You survey your one small room. The kitchen alcove has a refrigerator, a sink, a stove, and barely enough space to stand between them. One wall projects out to form a counter, with a cupboard beneath it.

The cupboard is open and bare.

The rest of the place is mostly filled by your futon, and the computer desk in the corner. The bathroom alcove is across from you, and the closet next to it. The stereo sits on a cardboard crate. A broad mirror tries to make the place seem twice its size; it halfway works. One window, whose shade is down, and the front door firmly shut.

The place is still too dim, except the corner where the desk lamp is somehow too bright.

Your luggage is piled untidily by the door. A potted hyacinth sits beneath the window.

On the desk are your to-do list and a travel book.

>
search under futon

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine stereo

The stereo is old, dating from the era when matte-black, featureless, and opaque were the watchwords of hipness. It still works, however.

>
turn on stereo

You step out of the kitchen nook.

The stereo buzzes, hunts, and then locates its station. Ah, your favorite small-time indy worldbeat/techno station. At least you think that's what they call it. It's a pretty stream-of-consciousness format.

The room fills with the sound of an Afro-Balinese song.

>
search behind stereo

You can't see any such thing.

>
attempt to open front door

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
open front door

The sun hasn't risen; what light you have would just leak out into the night. Anyway, the taxi hasn't arrived, so there's nowhere to go.

>
check luggage again for container or water

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the luggage.

>
search luggage

Oh, no. You spent hours jamming everything into the maximally packed configuration. If you disturb the luggage now, you fear, you'll still be repacking when the taxi arrives.

The radio begins playing a thumping Shaker song.

>
examine hyacinth for any water

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the hyacinth.

>
check if hyacinth pot has drainage tray for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the computer.

>
examine computer

You sit down at the desk.

The computer is years old, and incompatible with just about everything but electricity. You use it for writing -- at least, you try to believe that you do.

Right now, however, there's a game on the screen -- one of the text adventures, or interactive fictions, or whatever they are this month -- the only kind of game your beige antique can run, anyway.

The you-have-died message is blinking morosely at you. You started up Ready, Okay! last night, trying to distract yourself until morning. But you can't get even halfway through without running out of insulin.

You run your tongue over dry teeth.

>
examine insulin supplies

You can't see any such thing.

>
check if there's any water left in travel book

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the computer.

>
examine computer for anything useful

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the computer.

>
look for food in kitchen

You can't see any such thing.

>
search for small items in luggage

You can't see any such thing.

>
search desk for water or container

I only understood you as far as wanting to search the desk.

>
search desk

Aside from the computer, the lamp, and piles of paper, you see your to-do list and a travel book.

>
check travel book for useful items

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the travel book.

>
search travel book

The Schmendrick's Guide to Desert Camping -- you've been studying it for weeks now. Vast alien reams of information: perspiration rates, sunburn factors, tent guying, and how to make a condensation still out of a trashbag and a tin can. You could probably write the book out longhand from memory; and none of it means a damn thing to you.

>
try to remember condensation still instructions

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
read about condensation still

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine to-do list for any items

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine your to-do list.

>
check to-do list

The task list for your impending journey is a mess of crossed-out items and scribbled corrections. However, everything seems to have gotten done. The last line reads "Call taxi", and it has its checkmark, and here you wait.

The radio begins playing an Afro-Javanese tune.

>
look for something in luggage again

You can't see any such thing.

>
check if there's anything in the closet again

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the computer.

>
examine luggage for small items

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the luggage.

>
search more thoroughly through luggage

You can't see any such thing.

>
check under the desk

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine potted hyacinth again for hidden items

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the hyacinth.

>
examine hyacinth for hidden water sources

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the hyacinth.

>
search under the futon again

You can't see any such thing.

>
recheck kitchen for any hidden water sources

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
search kitchen again

I only understood you as far as wanting to search the kitchen nook.

>
examine refrigerator again

You can't see any such thing.

>
examine bathroom again for water

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the bathroom nook.

>
search bathroom again

I only understood you as far as wanting to search the bathroom nook.

>
check shower for anything useful

I only understood you as far as wanting to check the shower.

>
examine shower again

I only understood you as far as wanting to examine the shower.

>
search for hidden items in shower

You can't see any such thing.

>
check for items behind the toilet

You can't see any such thing.

>
review previous actions and options for new approach

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
examine everything in the apartment again

You can't see any such thing.

>
try to think of any other sources of water or containers in the apartment

That's not a verb I recognize.

>
search for water in the apartment

You can't see any such thing.

>

You can't see any such thing.

search for small containers in the living room
